awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:   Ship-based Technical Support in the Arctic (CY2014-2018): Science Services for Research onboard USCGC Healy
awd_abstract_narration: Scripps Institution of Oceanography and Oregon State University propose to support technical services for research on the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Healy. Healy is a research icebreaker operated by USCG in collaboration with NSF and other agencies that fund research in the Arctic. SIO and OSU will provide or coordinate the long-term maintenance and improvements to science systems onboard. They will provide technicians to operate scientific instruments and data systems on the Healy. They will arrange the use of items from the shared-use pools of science vans, coring equipment and other pooled equipment that is part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). SIO will provide one full-time person to act as a cruise planner and to coordinate the research needs for all cruises on Healy. The awardee will maintain updated content on the website http://icefloe.net. As needed the awardees will also assist the Arctic Sciences Section with coordinating science cruises on other national icebreakers to ensure safe and efficient operations. SIO and OSU will provide many coordination services including working with the USCG to perform upgrades to the ship for science and working with USCG and other ships operating in the Arctic to coordinate bathymetric mapping to ensure the most efficient and complete coverage is obtained each year to contribute to a more complete mapping of the Arctic Ocean, which is largely uncharted. Pending availability of funds, several system upgrades may be funded including the addition of a shallow-water multi-beam sonar for collecting bathymetric data in parallel with the existing multi-beam system that performs best in deep water. Each year of this five-year award will be funded based on the planned work at the start of each Arctic field season.

Ship-based Technical Support in the Arctic (STARC)

This award supported a successful collaboration between the Shipboard Technical Support (STS) department at Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) and the Marine Technician Group (MTG) at Oregon State University (OSU) to provide ship-based technical support in the Arctic aboard the USCGC Healy.  Managed by SIO, this project enabled professional, capable scientific technical support based on a model for the Arctic following best practices established within the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS).

 

Intellectual Merit

The observation, measurement, and collection of samples and data are accomplished in the Arctic by operations aboard icebreaking research vessels. The USCGC Healy has played a critical role in American exploration of the Arctic since entering service in 1999 and continues to contribute significantly to the American ocean research effort. The NSF STARC project enabled the involvement of highly-skilled professional marine technicians in Healy science operations.  Through their knowledge of and access to UNOLS education, training and best practices, SIO and OSU technicians leveraged the significant resources of UNOLS for the benefit of Arctic science conducted aboard Healy.

 

Under this award, STARC marine technicians applied an established pre-deployment planning process developed at SIO, so that scientific activities could be effectively planned, managed and executed in a manner that involved US Coast Guard operational personnel.  Marine technicians also facilitated the acquisition, installation, calibration, operation and maintenance of up-to-date scientific instrumentation. The knowledge, skill and abilities of STARC technical staff enabled instrumentation to be capably established into productive service aboard Healy for the benefit of the broad scientific community. All of these activities extended NSF's ability to support transformative scientific research into physical and biological processes in the Arctic environment, and enabled Healy to achieve its full potential as a remarkable engine for science and discovery in the Arctic.

 

Broader Impacts

The spectrum of research enabled by this award collectively achieved far-reaching broader impacts through the promotion of training and learning, by increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in research, by disseminating results to enhance scientific and technological understanding, and by informing policy making for the benefit of society. Students participated on many Arctic research cruises, and SIO and OSU technicians served as mentors to educate and train students in the appropriate use of technology at sea.  Technicians also trained and educated US Coast Guard technicians, and shared new tools and techniques with technicians throughout UNOLS, thus broadening the technical knowledge base that supports all U.S. oceanographic research.  The technical services provided under this award also supported the acquisition and handling of underway shipboard data so that, in concert with national resources such as the NSF-supported Rolling-Deck-To-Repository (R2R) program, shipboard data was transmitted to federal data centers in a timely, transparent and efficient manner, thus enabling accurate data to be made available to the scientific community and the public at large.
